div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,435] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, March 5, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage he made within 4 months of arrival, abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Rameses now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, March 5, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.

S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 17 for Malta, Gibraltar & Devoaport.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 15 for Livepool.
S.S. MANDALAY 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 29 for Liverpool.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

div.head: WHITE STAR LINE.
div.p: NEW YORK AND BOSTON MEDITERRANEAN SERVICE.

Regular Sailings between Alexandria , Naples, and Boston or New York, U.S.A. By the large modern twin screw steamers CELTIC, 21,000 tons- REPUBLIC, 15,400 tons- CANOPIC, 13,000 tons- ROMANIC, 11,400 tons.

Regular Service between Italy and United States throughout the year. Excellent accommodation for all classes of passengers. For plans of steamers, rates of passengers between the various ports, and full particulars, apply to THOS, COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor and Assouan; John Ross & Co., Alexandria; White Star Line, Via Roma, Gena, and 21, Piazza della Borsa, Naples.

NILE STEAMER SERVICES.
TOURIST SERVICE. — The large and splendidly appointed S.S. "Rameses the Great" will leave Cairo on March 6th for Luxor, Assuan and Philae.
This is the last departure of the Tourist Service for this season.
EXPRESS SERVICE. — Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday for Luxor, Assuan, and Philae. 19 days on the Nile for £22.

Regular service of freight steamers between Cairo & Halfa. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets. Tours to Palestine, Syria, and Desert. Best Equipment. Lowest charges.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about 8.80 a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 14 March, 1, 11 and 25 April; 7 and 21 May; 4 and 18 June.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 5 and 19 March.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 12 and 26 March; 9 and 23 April; 7 and 21 May; 4 and 18 June.
Far East Lines.

Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, and Kobe, about 5 March, 3 April, 4 May, 3 June, 4 July, 3 August. To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 8 and 17 March, 8 April, 8 May, 17 June. To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras Rangoon and Calcutta about 17 March, 19 April, 19 May. To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13 March, 13 April, 13 November, 13 December (Winter Line).
Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay and Durban about 5 March, 2 April and 3 May, 2 June, 3 July, 2 August, 2 September, 3 October, 2 November, 3 December.
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, LD., LEON HELLER, Cairo Agent, 24, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephons 192), Cairo; F. TEDESCHI, Helouan.
Special passage rates granted to Egyptian Government officials, members of the Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS, ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, MANSOURAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Reserve Fund . . £500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: Dedie aux Femmes Enceintes
div.p: Les femmes, en nombre de cas, savent mieux que bien des hommes, supporter sans failbir des souffrances inouies, honneur a elles! Nean-moins, n'est-ce pas folie que se resigner a endurer sans necessite, mille et une peines, au temps de la grossesse surtout? Apprenez donc, Mesdames, si vous ne le savez deja, qu'il existe un remede precieux.

qui est capable d'eloigner de vous tous malaises, toutes complications, de vous donner assez de force pour supporter aisement les petits ennuis communs a cette periode. Prenez-en, vous serez bientot soulagee et, par la meme occasion, assurerez au petit etre que vous portez en votre sein,

Editor and Manager . . R. SHELLING

div.head: THE RISING IN THE FRENCH SUDAN.
div.p: "The Manchester Guardian" makes the following interesting comments on the trouble in the Sudan: The destruction of a French post in the Sudan makes it fairly certain that the British disaster near Sokoto was not an incident in any mere local rising. The nearest point on the French frontier is at least 150 miles distant from Sokoto, and though the boundary represents no racial division, a movement which affects French and English alike at points one or two hundred miles apart must be due to some widespread political discontent. A new Mahdi, it is said, has arisen in the Western Sudan. We hope that is not true; but the time, was fear, may be ripe for another movement like that which overthrew the Egyptian rule in the Sudan was an unmitigated curse, while the English and French in the Western Sudan have probably improved the well-being of the majority of their subjects. But the Egpytians, after all were Mahomedans, and the French and English are not. A second Mahdi might have to play on a different string from the first, but the tune might be just as terrible. Our political distinctions between the Egyptian Sudan, Nigeria, and the French Sudan correspond to no reality. The Sudan is best thought of as one vast country stretching from Sokoto on the west to Khartaum on the east, and from Kano on the south to Morocco, Algeria, and Tripoli on the north. There is constant communication over the whole of this vast district. Placards issued by the Mahdi who overthrew Egyptian rule in the Eastern Sudan were found posted in a street of Bida, two thousand miles west of Khartoum; and when Lord Kitchener began his reconquest of the Sudan, the Khalifa urged the Sultan of Sokoto to make a diversion in his favour by driving the Christians out of Nigeria. The pressure on this fanatical Mahomedan population in the Sudan has now for many years been kept up from several sides at once from the Egyptian Sudan on the east, from the Mediterranean downwards by France, and from the Gulf of Guinea upwards through Nigeria by England. Almost all the Mahomedan tribes have a common grievance, and if a counterstroke were attempted the only wonder would be that it had been delayed so long. The present movement may not turn out to be so serious, but, whether it is or not, a general rising of the Mahomedan tribes in the Sudan must always be accounted one of the permanent dangers to the Anglo-French settlement in North Africa. It would not be in the least fanciful to suspect some connection between the rising in Sokoto and the Conference of Algeciras.

div.head: BRITISH RULE IN CYPRUS.
div.p: The "Courrier European" publishes an article by M. S. Skiadaresis, giving an account of the condition of affairs in Cyprus. The writer asserts that British rule has not improved the economic condition of the island, but has, of anything, made it worse. He ascribes this failure, first, to the saddling of the island with the payment of the 93,000 per annum which England agreed to make over to Turkey by the Treaty of June 4th, 1878; second, to the costly administration by high-salaried British officials; and, third, to the wasteful and sometimes (as in the case of the recent railway construction totally mistaken way of carrying out public works. The writer acknowledges that now, on account of this failure on the part of the British to improve matters, there in the island a widespread national feeling in favour of anuexation to Greece, and he expresses the hope that the new High Commissioner, Sir Charles King-Harman, to whom he gives every credit for his generosity and consideration in treating the natives, may yet plead the cause of the Cypriots before his Government.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Supreme Consular Court.
Judge Bettesworth Piggott has arrived in Cario on circuit, and stays at the Continental Hotel.
Coal Imports.
The imports of coal from January 1 to March 1 amounted to 177,337 tons, as compared with 95,568 tons last year.
Found Drowned.
The body of an unknown man was found floating in the Mahmoudieh Canal yesterday. It was taken out and sent to the hospital.
Minicipal Commission.
It is probable that the first meeting of the Commission of the Alexandria Municipality after the elections will be on Wednesday week.
"The Nile Quest."
A new edition of Sir Harry Johnston's "The Nile Quest" will be issued next week in "The Story of Exploration" series edited by J. Scott Keltie, LL.D.
Yacht in Harbour.
The P. & O. staem yacht Vectis arrived at Alexandria this morning from Jaffa with 168 tourists on board who have proceeded to Cairo. The Vectis leaves again on Friday for Naples.
The New Quay Lands.
As soon as the evaluation committee of the Alexandria Municipality has finished its valuation of the property in the new quay a certain quantity of land will be put up for auction.
Egyptian Estates.

We learn on reliable authority that the above company have resold a portion of the building estate in Alexandria which they recently purchased from Mr. G. B. Alderson at a price which leaves the company a profit of over 120 percent on their original price.
Cotton in Cyprus.

The latest Bulletin of the Imperial Institute an account is given of a visit recently paid by the Director of the Imperial Institute to Cyprus at the instance of the Colonial Office to enquire into the possibility of cotton cultivation and the general agricultural resources of the island.
Concert.

Tomorrow evening Mr. and Miss Kazanti will give their second concert at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria. We will publish the programme tomorrow. Tickets can be procured at the establishments of Messrs. Lifonti, Hakh, and Romanelli. The concert will begin at 9:15 p.m.
Alexandria Central Buildings Co.

We hear from London that the Anglo-Egyptian Bank has placed in London debentures of the Alexandria Central Buildings Company, Limited, to the value of £100,000 bearing interest at four per cent and redeemable in sixty years' time at the maximum or at any time prior to that date on receipt of notice one month in advance.
Bankruptcies.

The Mixed Commercial Court at Alexandria has declared the following persons bankrupt: Mohamed Akroa, Aly Abdel Guelil Cherif, Ahmed Mohamed, and G. Fracolo. Messrs. F. Raad & Co. and Mahmoud Hassan, and Mohamed Eclibe, who had been allowed to benefit by a "concordat preventif," have also been declared bankrupt as the Court refused to consider them as unfortunate and bona-fide debtors.
The Barbers' Strike.

On Saturday evening the whote of the master barbers of Alexandria with only three exceptions informed the men on strike that they would agree to accept the conditions demanded. Henceforth, therefore, the barbers' working day at Alexandria will be one of then and a half hours instead of twelve and a half, as before.
The three recalcitrant master barbers have been invited to attend at the Italian Consulate, where it is hoped that they will be induced to come into line with the other master barbers.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
div.p: AN INCIDENT.
AT THE ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Monday.

The Algeciras correspondent of the Paris "Matin" reports that on Friday evening, whilst the German and Italian diplomats were engaged in an animated conversation, the German evidently displeased the Italian, who arose, turning his back on the German, and retired to his apartments.
AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
NEW YORK, Monday.
BANKING DEVELOTMENTS
COMPTOIR D'ESCOMPTE

This morning, the inauguration of the headquarters in Egypt of the Comptoir Nationale d'Escompte de Paris" took place at the magnificent premises of the great French bank in the Palazzo Antoniadis at Alexandria.

Over a year ago the management at Paris decided, in view of the growing prosperity of Egpyt, to come here, and the old residence of the Antoniadis family was secured on a twenty years' lease, at a rental of £2,000 a year. Since then the building has been entirely transformed and a large part of the garden has been converted into a large and airy counting house.

The transformation of the building into a bank has been most successful from an architectural point of view, and the general effect is excellent. Extensive strong rooms have been constructed below the bank. At the entrance there is a luxurious reception room for the convenience of the clients and other visitors, whilst the first floor is devoted to the Accounts Department.

Mr. Llewelyn, the manager, is to be congratulated on having so successfully achieved the difficult task of converting a private residence into a bank. The contractors were Messrs. Degiarde Brothers and this local firm has done some excellent work in making the building suitable for a large financial establishment.
The headquarters of the Comptoir will be at Alexandria, but a branch is also to be opened at Cairo in a few months' time.
THE FITZNER QUARTETTE

The second and last concert of the season was given by this quartette at the New Khedivial Hotel on Thursday night before a large audience. While it would be presumption to attempt to pass judgement upon the performance, which was as perfect of its kind as anything we have ever heard, the programme did not perhaps fulfill all the expectations that a casual perusal of its contents might naturally arouse. The first time, quartette by Volkmann, in G minor was a very beautiful example of what absolute sympathy and unanimity will do in a string quartette, the performers indeed not only giving the impression of being of one mind, but it almost seemed as if their instruments were swayed by one hand. The andante movement of this piece, especially with its swelling cadences relieved by occasional plaintive touches, and passages of syncopation introduced so cleverly as to avoid all possibility of abruptness or too marked a contrast, was delightful, and one was left, when this piece terminated, with a strong hope that there were things as good or even better to come. It was to be regretted, however, that this piece should have been immediately followed by a characteristic but not very enlivening Andante funebro by Tachaikowsky. We do not care to be reminded of funerals on the rare occasions that we go forth to luxuriate in the embraces of the fickle muse, even through the medium of such a master in the expression of the tragic in musical art as this composer. His tragedy has perhaps too much pessimism and too little grandeur to be always very satisfying. But the music of its kind was beautiful and one could detect occasional faint reminiscences of the famous "Pathetique" which made one feel at home. An Allegro vivo of Dvorak's came as a somewhat welcome relief. We now pass to the 'Beethoven' in A minor, an impressive but rather unintelligible work in four movements, the third movement in which takes the form of on ode written to a divinity in gratitude for a cure. It contains a beautiful chorale, with the tonic F, but in strict accordance with the moda in which it is written; the B in the scale is natural, and this would account for the rather unexpected harmonies this piece contained, which sometimes left one in doubt as to what the composer was driving at. It is one of the very rare examples of a piece written strictly in accordance with this ancient musical mode. By special request, at the end of the performance, a quartette of Griegs was given, and in this the performers surpassed themselves. No composer seems to combine genuine melody with a solid background of grand and impressive harmonies and this composer does, and the piece sent one home with a feeling of gratitude for a fitting termination to what had proved a regular festa of musical enjoyment.

div.head: FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: THE NOUR EL BAHR.
DELEGATES' MYSTERIOUS DEPARTURE
(From OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez, Saturday.

The Coast Guard cruiser Nour el Bahr sailed from Suez yesterday morning for Akaba with Government stores and despatches for H.M.S. Diana, which is still anchored at Farson island to prevent the Turkish troops occupying it.
It is stated that at present the Turkish forces at Taba amount to about 5,000 men, with artillery.
It is quite certain that the first time the Nour el Bahr went to Akaba and sent out a boat with officers and men, the Turks refused to allow them to land, and ordered them to go back to the ship.
The Turkish delegates for the frontier dispute, Colonel Muzaffer Pacha and Bimbashi Fehmy, have left Cairo for, it is said, Bayrout. It is surmised that they will start thence for Ma'an.
THE PILGRIMAGE.

Ibrahim Pasha Fathy, the Emir el Hag, has written to the Ministry of the Interior stating that he has agreed with the Sherif of Mecca and the Vali of the Hedjaz that the Holy Carpet should be conveyed from Mecca to Medina by the direct route; and that the camels needed for the pilgrims have been hired at the rate of L.E. 15 each, to travel from Mecca to Medina and thenpe to Yambo.
The Mahmal will arrive at Yambo on tha 20th inst., and the Khedivial Mail Line have been warned to prepare their steamers for the conveyance of the Egyptian pilgrims on that date.
THE HOHENZOLLERN.
Tbe Russian packet landed twenty-five of the Hohenzollern's passengers from Candia at Alexandria on Saturday afternoon. Among these passengers were Consul General von Hartmann and his family.

The remainder of the passengers, including tbe Archduke Joseph and the Archduchess Augusta of Austria will arrive from Candia at Alexandria by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Schleswig at daybreak tomorrow.
PHENOMENON SEEN AT LUXOR.

Lieut.-Gereral Fred. Lance writes to us from Luxor under date of 8atnrday: Yesterday afternoon about ten minutes to six o'olock, and a little time before the sun set behind tbe Theban hills, I was near the temple of Mut when I saw a brilliant meteor falling in a perpendicular direction. It disappeared behind a clump of palm trees. A gentleman and his daughter saw this meteor from tbe great pylon of the Temple of Karnak; from that point they state that they saw it burst laterally and disappear. They noticed the brilliancy of the meteor, especially at the time of bursting. As the appearance of a meteor in broad daylight is unusual it would be interesting to know whether the phenomenon was observed in other parts of Egypt.
Sudan Notes.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
E. Oheid, February 16.

We have had very unseasonable weather here lately. A few days ago we had a very bad dust storm which lasted all day and was most unpleasant. On the 15th, whilst we were at dinner, we had a little rain, which is very unusual here so early in the year. It has been very hot lately.

Major Ravenscroft and his new mufattish Mr. Geeve are up here. They have got a lot of good recruits for the Slavery Repression Department and are busy training them. The former leaves for Cairo in a few days.
Several new buildings are in course of erection and are badly needed.
We have great festivities during the visit of the Bishop of Hereford here, including parties, assault-at-arms, and a football match between the 8th and 12th Battalions at which the Bishop kicked off.
MISSIONS ON THE UPPER NILE

The headquarters of the mission to the pagan races of the Upper Nile, which recently received the sanction of Lord Cromer, will not, (the "Tribune" hears), be at Mongalla, which has just been safely reached, but at a point much lower down the river. Thirty years ago the necessity for such a mission was urged by General Gordon. The first tribes to be approached are the Dinkas, a warlike and savage people. Dr. Albert Cook, who arrived from Uganda some weeks in advance of the pioneer bands, found that Mongalla was not the most favourable spot for commencing work. It is interesting to note that the missionaries received help from the Commandant at Fashoda, who sent his steamer to tow the sailing vessel through the sudd.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Ellerman S.S. Ararat arrived at Liverpool last Friday morning.
The Ellerman S.S. City of Khios sailed last Saturday for Manchester with a general cargo, including 7,862 bales cotton and 774 cases eggs.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due at Alexandria tomorrow.

div.head: ABYSSINIANS AND COPTS.
div.p: THE DEIR ESSULTAN.
ABYSSINIANS GAIN THE DAY.
Jerusalem, February 24.

A dispute of long standing between the Abyssinians and Copts, dating as far back as tho middle of last century, regarding the ownership of the convent called 'Deir es Sultan," adjacent to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, for which question the Emperor Menelik has sent of late years two special missions to the Sultar, accompanied with costly and rare presents, has at last been adjusted to the satisfaction of the Abyssinians. His Excellency Rechid Bey, the Governor of Jerusalem, acting under orders from the Sublime Porte, has this day caused a separate entrance to the said convent to be opened with a view of handing over its key to General Machachs, the head of the Abyssinian Mission, who has recently returned from Constantinople.

The Sultan had a short time previously issued an Imperial Irade to the effect that the Copts should be called upon to cede to the Abyssinisns a duplicate key of the old door of the convest in question, but the Coptic Bishop of Jerusalem persisted in declining to carry out the request of the Imperial 'Government or to grant any concession whatsoever. In order to avoid using compulsion, the Governor, who acted throughout with tact and moderation suggested, and tbe Porte concurred, that instead of a duplicate key being given by the Copts a separate gateway to the convent might be opened from the street for the use of the Abyssinan, who from ancient times have been inhabiting the said monastery. Thus the site becomes now practically the property of both sects.

In former time, the Abyssinians, acoording to hints in eccleaiastical history, had considerable possessions within the Holy City, of which they have been deprived, so that there remained only the convent of "Deir es Sultan" above referred to (in which there are at present about 70 Abyssinian monks and pilgrim) which the Copts have been claiming as their own, alleging that the Abyssinians were admitted therein on sufferance, owing to their being in intercommunion with them. In fact, the Copts have been the masters of the place since tbe door was under their control, and the inmates were locked in or allowed exit whenever they chose. The Abyssinians, on the other hand, could not prove by documentary evidence that the convent really belonged to them, for, in 1839, at the time of the Egyptian occupation of Syria, it happened that all the Abyssinians in Jerusalem died at plague and their library, containing many valuable manuscripts, was then entirely burnt by Ibrahim Pacha, at the instigation of the Armenians under the pretext of danger of infection, with all the documents which might have served them to recover their property in these better times. At any rate Dr. Gobat, once Anglican Bishop in Jerusalem, in a statement made by him on this question in 1852, wrote: "I have myself seen the library 25 years ago together with such documents, and that all those books and documents were consigned to the flames on the aforesaid occasion is most notorious in Jerusalem."

It will not be without interest to mention in this connection that in 1866, when King Theodorus of Abyssinia detained in captivity within his dominions a number of Englishmen, which culminated in a British expedition against his country, that monarch alleged that his action was a retaliation for the indifference displayed by England to his repeated appeals to the British Government for the recovery of the "Deir-es-Sultan" convent from the Copts, and in consequence of that statement the question of that monastery formed the subject of a special Blue Book, which was laid before Parliament in 1867.
THE LATE MIDDLEMASS BEY.

Commander Middlemass Bey, late Chief Inspector of the Egyptian Coast Guard, whose death our London Correspondent announced on Friday, had a good deal of naval service to his credit. He first served in the Active daring the Ashantee War, 1873-74, receiving the Ashantee medal for his services. He was highly commended in despatches and promoted for service in tbe expedition up the Congo against pirates in 1875. His other services were: Lieut. in the Thalia durirg Egyptian war 1882; employed in transport service (Egyptian Medal Khedive's Bronze Star); appointed Inspector General of the Egyptian Coast Guard service in May, 1B84, and in March, 1885, awarded by the Khedive the rank of Bey, in recognition of his zeal and ability whilst holding that post. While in the Egyptian service he was present at the defeat of the Dervishes outside Suakin by Sir F. Grenfell, K.C.B., (Sirdar), 20th December, 1888; mentioned in despatches; Gemaizah clasp; permitted by the Queen to accept and wear the Insignia of the Order of the Medjidiah of the Third Class, which the Khedive had conferred upon him in recognition of services whilst employed in the service of the Egyptian Government. He was granted the rank of Miralei by the Khedive in Dec., 1892. In April, 1896, he retired on pension from the Egyptian Government Service receiving the personal thanks of H. H. tbe Khedive for services rendered as Inspector General of Coast Guard, Salt, and Fishery Services, the tobacco revenue alone having been raised from £ 106,000 to £l,000,000 during his term of service. He held the rank of Grand Officer of the Imperial Order of the Medjidieh.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: ATTRACTIONS AND AMUSEMENTS.
SUCCESSFUL AMATEUR THEATRICALS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENNT).
Helouan, Friday.

Many are the reasons given for facilitating by rail and road the communications between Cairo and Helonan, and yet all things considered Helonan would lose its chief charms if it were brought into closer touch with the noise and bust of the big city and became merged into a mere suburb. As it stands now its chief joys are to be found in its perfect peace and rest, its glorious air, and the simplicity of life, all of which would become impossible if it ever became merely the annexe to crowded Cairo. From time to time the greater world swarms into it but for the moot part tbe visitors spend their days in healthy open air pursuits and their nights in health-giving repose, and there are but few who would change their lot for tbe attractions of tbe social merry-go round of the hub of Egypt.
Social Gatherings.

Not that one need forswear society altogether in Helonan, for many are tbe gatherings, race meetings, dances, and entertainments which are provided by and for the more energetic and these are always well attended insomuch that visitors have not tbe same chance of being satisfied by a plethora of them. The Casino was very full on Thursday evening when an excellent company of amateurs gave a very successful entertainment in aid of the organ fund for tbe English Church. Theatricals are always a great attraction, and Mrs. Warren, Miss Hobson, and Miss Tottenham did their best for the littte comedietta "Petticoat Perfidy," which was the first item of the programme. One could have wished to see these ladies in some other characters, for they had but little plot and next to no humour. Mrs. Warren made a charming little French maid, and spoke her lines prettily enongh when her voice got used to the stage; but Miss Tottenham's part was uncongenial, nor was Miss Hobson's role a sympathetic one. Mr. Trimen gave a couple of good comic songs, notably a mock passionate love song with its refrain "Mingle your eyebrows with mine, love," whioh called forth an encore, and Mr. Hans Sawyer, who is an elocutionist of no little merit, gave a very successful and amusing "Engine driver's story" with local allusions.
Mrs. Jarley's Waxworks.

The second half of the evening's entertainment was given over to the performance of Mrs. Jarley's Waxworks, that celebrated showwoman being impersonated by Mr. Madden, while Mr. Hans Sawyer made a most praiseworthy George. The vargaries of the "waxworks" and their mechanical irresponsibilities and breakdowns were very cleverly rendered, and tbe witticisms of Mrs. Jarley and George were at times exceedingly to the point. Much praise is due to the figure for their actions and utterances, Miss Tottenham being especially clever in her wooden movements and incontrollable actions. Mr. Charlesworth played his part of a very "SimpleSimon" and Mr. Lord made an excellent "Fat Joe." "Mary and her lamb," and "Bopeep" never looked prettier than when enacted by Visa L Zahotkine and Miss Bentley respectively, and Miss Babbington Jones' voice as "Signs Squallina" will not easily be forgotten. Mr. Ford made many great hits as a "Professional Golfer," and Miss Zabotkine as the "Baby on the Shore" had the sympathy of the entire house when she was brought to bay under an empty crate at the termination of the proceedings. It is estimated that about £50 has been made by the entertainment, and if so it will not be long before the church is in possession of the organ it so badly requires.
Race Meeting.

The race meeting today brought together the usual number of people and proved a thoroughly enjoyable afternoon but for the unfortunate mishap that caused Mr. Michaeli does a nasty spill during the last race. He had been more than usually lucky during the earlier afternoon and most people would have been glad to see him score another win. Among those noticed in the enclosure were Mr. and Mrs. Satow, the Misses Hurley, Miss Fullerton, Mrs. Smart, Mrs. Freeman, Dr. Graf, Mr. Payne, Miss Wait, the Hon. F. Morgan, Mr. Draper, Mr. Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips, Mr. Doherty, Mrs. Shepperd, Capt. and Miss Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Huteson, Mrs. and the Misses Bentley, Major Watson, Mrs. Warren, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Capt. Outram, Miss Darley, Miss Duncan, Mr. Lord, Mrs. Hopkinson, Mr. Carter-Wilson, Col. Sparkes, Aziz Pacha Izzat, Ahmed Bey Bakri, and Mrs. and the Misses Zabotkine.
BAND PERFORMANCE.

By kind permission of Lt. Col. C. J. Markham and officers, the band of the 1st Batt. King's Royal Rifles will peform the following selection of music at Ghezireh Palace on Wednesday. 7th inst. from 4 to 6 p.m.
1 Marche-Lorriane-Ganne
2 Oventure-Le Domino Noir-Auber
3 Intermezzo-Salome-Loriani
4 Grand Fantasia on Irish Airs-Erin-Basquit
5 Valse Lente-Response a Amoureuse-Berger
6 Morceau Mignon-Salut d'Amour-Elgar
7 Selection-The Blue Moon-Rubens
8 Galop-John Peel-Brown.
Regimental March.-Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
THOMAS BROWN, Bandmaster.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Cromer and her sister, Lady Beatrice Thynne, her son, the Hon. Evelyn Baring, and suite have returned to Cairo from Mena House, where the air has done the young child a deal of good, the weather being at its best now at Mena.
Three birthdays of prominent Anglo-Egyptians feel last week. Lord Cromer was born on the Feb. 26, 1841, Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield on March 3, 1835, and Judge Marshall on the same day in 1864.

Mr. and Mrs. Brodrick and Miss Sybil Brodrick after their visit to Egypt will probably go to India. About a year ago it seemed possible that Mr. Brodrick would go to India under very different circumstances. Unless rumour was quite wrong, Mr. Baltour was on the point of recommending the appointment of Mr. Brodrick to be Lord Curson's successor as Viceroy of India. It such was his intention it came to nought, for the cabled rumour roused such opposition in India, as well as at home that Mr. Brodrick's chance was gone.

Mr. Anderson Fowler, one of the pioneers in the packing industry and for many years the president of the Anglo-American Packing & Provision Company, has died while touring Egpyt. Two other members of the Fowler family died from diseases contracted in Egpyt, Robert E. Fowler and the Rev. James W. Fowler, brothers of Andesen Fowler, being poisoned by the drinking water.

Mr. Fowler leaves an estate estimated at $15,000,000 to be distributed among the widow and nine children. The property consists of large holdings of timber lands in the South and West. Mr. Fowler was in the packing business for more than 30 years. In 1902, he sold out to the National Packing Company. Mr. Fowler was 53 years old. For the last 15 years he had lived in New York.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night: Messrs. E. Tanket and C. T. Battie, Misses Borwich, Mr. Borwich, Mr. Pelizaeus, Mr. Manson, Comtesse Grother, Mr. Wolff, Mr. Bock, Mr. Vendscher, Mr. Barthes, Cook's Moltke party of 7.

The following is the passenger list of the S.S. Mayflower, which left on Friday for the Nile: Mr. and Mrs. M. A. Bush, Mrs. Palfrey, Dr. and Miss Grace Merrill, Miss Nedham, Mr. and Mme Geromichas, Mr. and Mrs. Silas Peirce, Miss Elizabeth Peirce, Dr. Dunning, Mr. and Mrs. H. F. Downing, Miss Elizabeth Hicks, Miss M. Hicks, Mr. Holaman, Mrs. and Miss Keitt, Mr. and Mrs. I. F. King, Mrs. E. Care, Mr. Henrick Hirsch, Mr. and Mrs. Kriesteller, Mr. and Mrs. Ravensberg, Miss M. A. Bayley, Mrs. C. W. S. Cobb, Mrs. C. M. Adams, Dr. 0 H. Reisser, Mrs. A. J. Tullock, Miss L. M. Tullock, Miss F. L. Tulock, Mr. and Mrs. J. Letchworth, Mr. G. Letchworth, Miss Letchworth, Miss Watson, Rev. and Miss. Milliken, Mr. and Mrs. Majo, Miss Kate R. Andrews, Mrs. G. Yeoman, Mrs. C. B. Stuart, Mrs. T. A. Stuart, Miss R. Morrill, Miss Alice Earl, Mr. and Mrs. N. F. Vanderlyn, Miss A. M. Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. P. N. Nunn, Mr. Nunn's Sec., Rev. and Mrs. W. A. Schaeffer, Mr. and Mrs. H. Post, Mr. and Mrs. Z. D. Mathuss, Mr. and Mrs. E. P. Bosbyshell, Mrs. C. Frost, Mrs. A. Frost-Stout, Mrs. Everett Fowler, Mrs. M. E. Showers, Mr. and Mme Pierre Labbe, Mr. Alegernon Carver, Miss Carver, Mrs. Macaulay.
NOTES FROM SUEZ.
RETURN OF H.M.S. DONEGAL.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Sunday.

H. M.'s first-class cruiser Donegal, which was ashore at Tor Bank, in the Suez Gulf, was refloated, as I informed you by wire, last Friday evening, and as she sustained very slight damage she apparantly must have proceeded. She is bound for China and will call at Aden, Colombo, and Shanghai.
The British homeward-bound steamer Ratho has been ashore in the Canal, between 152 Kilo. station and Port Tewfik, since early this morning and is blocking the way. All traffic is stopped.
The Khedivial mail liner Rahmanieh arrived at Suez yesterday from Tor with a large number of Egpytian pilgrims, who are the first to return. The health of the pilgrims is good.
Suez, Later.
The S.S. Ratho has been refloated this afternoon with the assistance of the Canal Company's tug Titan.
Suez, Monday.
H.M.S. Donegal has returned to Suez this morning.
